posts.cooked:
I am from team 2611. Our programming team is made up of 3 programmers who have never use java and one programmer who used java but not a lot.

We got a drive program working on a robot this past week, but when we try to disable through the driver station the robot code appears to delete. When we turn off and back on our robot, the code reappears.

The roborio firmware is up to date (172.22.11.2) and we are using the 2022 driver station and 2022 VS code. We think it might be something in our firmware.

Any help appreciated, Team 2611

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: When you hit the disable button, do you get a stacktrace ? That would be useful to understand the root of the issue.

link_counts.title: Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
It’s very unlikely that this is an issue in the roborio firmware.  As @gerthworm mentioned, you most likely have an error/stacktrace in your driver station output/riolog console, which would indicate your code is crashing.

Also, if you share your code (ideally as a link to github or similar), we can take a look and help identify the cause.

I do not see this error in the driver station when I disable teleop. I checked and there was no error in the driver station. The robot does not stop unexpectedly when we drive. If you don’t think it is a firmware issue do you have an idea as to what it might be?
I do not have a copy of the code right now bit I will have one first thing in the morning.

Here is the link to the github code.

Contribute to saratippie/Drive-Code development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
There are a number of improvements you could make in your code (like having your same side motor controllers follow the other), or use dependency injection when building your commands to make sure your robot state is what you’d expect when scheduling default commands etc.

All that said, I don’t see anything special that would be causing a complete crash upon disabling the robot.

You should run this code with the RioLog tool running in VS Code to see if you get any output that you can easily copy and paste the text here for us to look at.

Vector2611:

We got a drive program working on a robot this past week, but when we try to disable through the driver station the robot code appears to delete.

Sorry if I missed this scrolling through, but what does appears to delete mean? What is the status string on the driver station, “No Robot Code” or just “Disabled?” If you click Enable on the driver station again, what happens? And are you enabling in teleop when you try it again?

Obviously the code isn’t “deleted” if you reboot the roborio and it starts up again. And you don’t see any errors. So it would help to know what makes you think it is deleted.

I believe this will be a problem in your code:

When your command ends, the end() function will be called. What does this.end(interrupted) do? Hint, look up super for Java, but it won’t end up being needed in this case anyway.

Should have poked around a bit more before replying (and not reply to myself), but I also don’t think you want to do the following:

Is there a need to set a default command over and over on a periodic basis?

Thanks for replying. It ended up being the “this.end(interrupted);” line of code. We took out that line and it worked. The robot code does not disappear when we disable now. Thanks for your help, Team 2611

Excellent. Hopefully you understand what was happening somewhat.

And take a look at the wpilib documentation and examples for the Command Base Programming again. It will save you some trouble in the long run.
